question.title: MessageFormat.format() gives ClassCast exception
question.body:
The following code snippet throws a ClassCastException.

I know how to fix it, but I'm disappointed that I have to fix it at all, as the Javadoc seems to indicate this should work. But the implementation tries to cast it to an Array (without checking).

  @Test
  public void testHelloWorldFormat() {
    MessageFormat fmt = new MessageFormat(
        "Hello, {0}.");

    assertThat(fmt.format("world")).isEqualTo("Hello, world.");
  }

I have to write it according to the following, and I don't like it:

  @Test
  public void testHelloWorldFormat() {
    MessageFormat fmt = new MessageFormat(
        "Hello, {0}.");

    assertThat(fmt.format(new String[] { "world" })).isEqualTo("Hello, world.");
  }

What i'd really like to see is a MessageFormat.format(Object ...), but there isn't one?

Relevant link: javadoc of MessageFormat.

question_comments.body: What is the actual question here? (Please edit the question to clarify.) I presume it's not "but there isn't one?", because you're clearly looking at the relevant API docs, so you must already know there isn't.

Unfortunately, MessageFormat overrides that method and seems to change the contract to what @JonSkeet quoted. It's specified to cast the object to an array for whatever reason. This appears to be a problem unique to the MessageFormat implementation.
The Format#format(Object) method is equivalent to format(obj, new StringBuffer(), new FieldPosition(0)).toString();. That latter format method says it treats the first argument as a single object.
There is a static method format(String, Object...). Is that not suitable?

"as the Javadoc seems to indicate this should work" - could you clarify exactly what in the Javadoc leads you to expect that will work? The Javadoc I'm reading now seems to indicate there'll be a cast to Object[]: "This is equivalent to format((Object[]) arguments, result, pos)"
